text.p: These are the leading stories in the Kenyan press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Ruling party Kenya African National Union (KANU) comes under fire from National Convention Executive Council and National Council of Churches of Kenya for saying it will not discuss constitutional reforms with non-elective bodies.
- KANU reiterates stand that political reforms will be discussed only in parliament with elected leaders.
- Opposition FORD-Kenya party decides for sake of party's survival not to discipline vice-chairman James Orengo, accused of contradicting party chairman.
- Police fire in air to disperse rowdy crowds outside parliament.
- Central Bank Governor Cheserem appointed for second four-year term.
- President Moi tells police officers to ensure they do not victimise innocent people.
- Official documents belonging to teachers destroyed by mysterious fire at Teachers Service Commission headquarters.
- Presidential hopeful Charity Ngilu has formed private security team to protect her during campaign.
- Details emerging from last week's meeting of National Executive Committee of KANU indicate sharp divisions on position party should take on constitutional reforms.
